title: Intersectionality & Health Disparities Analysis
summary: Examining how intersecting social positions shape health disparities using pooled NHIS data and the Evans et al. framework.
overview: This project examines how intersecting social positions—race/ethnicity, sex, nativity, and socioeconomic status—combine to shape disparities in self-rated health. Using pooled, multi-year NHIS data, the study replicates and extends the intersectionality framework introduced by Evans et al. (2018), producing domain-specific health estimates that highlight heterogeneity within and across demographic groups. The goal is to provide a more nuanced understanding of structural health inequities beyond single-variable analyses.
myRole: I co-lead the analytic and data engineering workflow, with a focus on methodological fidelity, harmonization across survey periods, and reproducible computation.

sections.title: Survey Harmonization & Data Preparation
content: Developed harmonized datasets across multiple NHIS redesigns, resolving inconsistencies in demographic, nativity, and socioeconomic variables.
Standardized classification rules for race/ethnicity, sex, nativity, education, and poverty ratio to ensure comparable grouping across pooled periods.
Constructed 8 intersectional domains consistent with Evans et al. and adapted them for newer survey cycles.

sections.title: Intersectionality Framework Implementation
content: Replicated the analytic structure from Evans et al. using complex survey weights and design-adjusted variance estimation.
Implemented domain-level prevalence estimation for self-rated health across multiple pooled periods.
Developed procedures to evaluate magnitude and direction of disparities across intersectional groups, including domain contrasts and trend stability checks.

sections.title: Quality Assurance & Reproducibility
content: Built systematic QA checks: drift detection, missingness profiles, cross-tab validation, denominator consistency, and weight stability across periods.
Established a version-controlled workflow for all harmonization rules, analytic steps, and output tables.
Collaborated closely with faculty investigators to align analytic decisions with intersectionality theory and the methodological constraints of complex survey design.

technologies: Complex survey methods (stratification, PSUs, variance estimation)
Intersectionality methods (Evans et al. replication and extension)
outcomes: Produced analysis-ready, harmonized datasets for multi-period intersectionality studies.
Replicated core findings from foundational literature and extended analyses to newer NHIS periods.
Generated domain-level health disparity estimates supporting a manuscript currently in development.
Improved analytic reliability through standardized QA protocols, reproducible code, and methodological transparency.
